mid0: Past are the days of Troy's mighty walls...
Ten years of war brought only misery and loss for the Ilians. Now only echoes linger of the once unconquerable nation, reverberating all across the earth.
But amidst the crumbling ruins and fading memories, a great leader will emerge, one whose destiny is woven from Troy's great legacy.
Son of Venus, great forefather of the Roman Empire, this is the story of

text: Storm clouds gather above your fleet. As the rain begins to trickle down, you are filled with a sense of dread...
All at once the storm breaks- winds billow about, hoping to force you overboard.
Your crew desperately fights to keep their ships under control, looking to you for guidance.
You give a valiant effort, but the storm overpowers you.
Your fleet is flung about, waves crash all around you. You watch as a wall of water rises and engulfs a nearby ship, sinking it under the darkened waters.
You lose all control- you can only watch helplessly as the gales force your ships into all different directions. Your own boat continues to groan under the strain of the elements.
Then, as suddenly as they had angered, the winds calm.
The waters relent and guide you to a nearby shore. You land the remaining ships and your people gather around you.

choices.text: Tell them to rest- you'll need to move on soon

text: "My friends, we are no strangers to suffering. But know that the gods hold us in their favor."
"With their help we will surely persevere to Latium and build a new Trojan kingdom."
"Until then we must endure our fortune and have faith that it will change."
"Rest well tonight- we have found ourselves on unknown shores and must stay on guard."
"We cannot lose sight of our destiny, and we must leave as soon as possible."
You set up camp on the shore and sleep. Once dawn breaks, you decide to scout out the surrounding area, which looks wild.
Deep in the woods you come across a young huntress, a bow slung over her shoulder.
"Please, have you come across one of my sisters? She has a quiver and is wearing a spotted lynx skin and a belt."

choices.text: You sense something strange about her

text: "No, I haven't seen or heard your companion. But- what are you? No mortal has such a voice or face."
"Please goddess, have compassion, and tell me where misfortune has landed my people."
"I promise you many sacrifices at your altar."
"Surely I would not be deserving of such offerings", the girl replies.
"But I can tell you where you've landed. You are in Punic territory, surrounded by many unconquerable African cities."
"We are led by queen Dido- whose story I can briefly share with you."

"She was originally Phoenician, married to wealthy Sychaeus. Her brother, king Pygmalion, murdered Sychaeus out of greed. In a dream her husband revealed to her a secret treasure and urged her to escape."
"Gathering the wealth and any friends who wished to join her, she left her home to found this rising city of Carthage."
"But who are you? What country do you come from and where are you going?"
"I am Aeneas, my people are from the ancient city of Troy. A storm has forced us to these shores as we seek Italy, our ancestors' homeland."

The huntress carefully responds: "I can assure you, the favor of the gods has brought you here. My parents taught me to read the skies, and the birds above give good omens! Go to the queen's home, you'll find your lost comrades there and their ships safe."

choices.text: Go back to the shore where you left your fleet

text: You decide to follow her advice and visit the Carthaginian queen. As the girl turns to leave, she changes into the form of a true god.
You recognize Venus, your mother. You call out to her, but she has already disappeared.
Frustrated by the trick, you walk towards the city's walls. As you do, a thick cloud comes down to cover you, hiding you from any interference.
You walk through the city, shrouded in Venus' mist. The bustling city boasts many construction projects, and already their walls seem tall and powerful.
As you approach a great temple to Juno, you see Dido herself, followed by a large procession of young men.

You recognize some faces that had been whisked away by the storm. Waiting by the entrace, you hear the lost Trojans plead their case with Dido, sharing the story of their sacked city and the long voyage they'd endured.
Dido listens and tells them to calm themselves. She promises support for the Trojans, either to help send them away or build a new life in Carthage.
"I only wish the storm had brought your king Aeneas himself- I will send some men to search for him."
Without warning, the cloud covering you rips apart, revealing you to the queen and her visitors.
Surprised for only a moment, you speak: "Here I am, saved from the relentless sea."

"You are the first to pity us, the scraps left behind by the Greeks. Our people are eternally grateful for your selflessness, and surely the gods and your own conscience will reward you for such an act."
Still amazed at your sudden appearance, the queen watches in silence as you re-unite with your lost men. Finally, she speaks to you:
"I can only imagine what cruel fate has hounded you through endless dangers. I have heard of you before, from Greek kings and warriors who fought at Troy and who admire your ancient lineage."
"I am no stranger to suffering myself, such a life has taught me compassion. Please, have you and your men join me for a feast at the palace!"

choices.text: Return to the shores and the rest of your men

text: You accept, following Dido as she gives sacrifices at different temples, eventually leading you to a regal dining hall.
You tell one of your men to go back to your ships and bring your son to the palace, along with gifts for the queen.
Your son, Ascanius, arrives, and the feast begins. The queen offers up a speech:
"They say Jupiter is the god of guests- let him make this a good day for our new Trojan friends! Joyful Bacchus, good Juno, let this union be the beginning of many good things to come!"
As the night goes on, Dido continues to draw closer to you.

She asks you about your past- stories of Priam, Hector, and Achilles. "Tell me everything, from the start- the war, your city's fall, your wanderings across the earth. Please, share with us your story!"
Now all the feast's attendants have turned to look at you, expectantly.

choices.text: Tell about the Fall of Troy

text: "I've not seen anyone, but you should worry about yourself."
You draw your sword. "Tell me, what place is this- what people live here? Answer or you may never be re-united with your companion again."
She stares at you, devoid of any fear. Her eyes are piercing, and you are overwhelmed by the sense that you've made a mistake.
"You are in Punic territory, surrounded by many unconquerable African cities. Queen Dido is our ruler, a Phoenician who fled her native land to found this city."
She pauses, before continuing, "She is be expecting you. I would advise you to pay her a visit."

choices.text: Go back to the shore where you left your fleet

text: You have a strange feeling about this encounter.
You slowly back away from the huntress, before turning and running back to your ships and the shore.
Your crew is happy to see you return. You begin to set up camp on the shoreline- it will take some time to repair your damaged ships.
Over the next weeks, your progress slowly continues. Your days are spent toiling under the sun, your nights are plagued by dreams, visions of your past and future.
On one particularly restless night, you find yourself back within Ilium's walls, at the beginning of the end.

choices.text: Dream of the Fall of Troy

text: You thank her for her advice, but explain to her that you need to get back to your wrecked ships. You tell her you don't plan on staying here any longer than you need to.
She gives you a reluctant farewell and you go your separate ways.
You thank the queen for her hospitality, but explain to her that you need to get back to your wrecked ships. You tell her you can't stay in Carthage any longer than you have to.
She wishes you well and you lead your lost men back to be re-united with their companions.
After years of war, we thought that we had broken the spirits of the Greeks. They had retreated, leaving nothing behind but a large wooden horse.
Trojans gathered around the beast- some were ready to accept the gift, others were rightfully skeptical.
Laocoon, a priest of Neptune, rushed from the town. "Trojans, have you lost your minds? No gift of the Greeks can be sincere! They must be hiding in the machine, planning our demise!"
With this proclamation, he picked up a spear and hurled it into the horse. A resounding groan was heard from within.
Surely we would have realized the trap and descended upon the contraption with a violent fury, if it hadn't been for the next phase of the Greek's trick.
A captive was led to our group, one apprehended by a group of shepards. We questioned him, asking for his history and his intentions.
He introduced himself as Sinon, a Greek who had accompanied Palamedes in the war. He spoke of Palamedes' tension with Ulysses, and how after his friend's death Ulysses had continued to persecute him.
He told us how the Greeks, worn out from years of war, had decided to leave, and sent a soldier, Eurypylus, to seek advice from the oracle.
He continued, "The oracle demanded a sacrifice for a safe return- the life of a Greek soldier. Ulysses went to Calchas, our seer, demanding the name of the man to be sacrificed."

"For ten days, Calchas refused to sentence someone to death. But, driven by Ulysses' force, he finally spoke, declaring me to be the gift. A cruel plan by Ulysses, still seeking revenge- they chained me, preparing me for my death, but I broke free, hiding until they sailed away. Now I can never return to my homeland."
We fell for his lies, freeing him of his binds and asking what he knew of the wooden horse.

choices.text: Still skeptical, we sent him away

text: We fell for his lies, freeing him of his binds and asking what he knew of the wooden horse.
"By the eternal fires and sacred Troy, and by the god's ribbons condemning me, it is only right for me to betray the Greeks, to hate them. I will reveal all."

"The Greeks relied on the power of Pallas to win this war. After Ulysses and Diomedes' raid on her temple, and the abduction of the Palladium from its shrine, the goddess turned on us, sending divine signs that we were no longer in her favor."

"This was why they decided to retreat, in hopes of returning after regathering their godly allies. This offering is meant as an offering to the violated godhead, a gift to Minerva herself, to be brough within your city's walls."

choices.text: We accepted the horse into our city
We could not shake suspicion, deciding to leave the horse outside

text: Despite Sinon's elaborate story, we were still reluctant to bring the huge statue within our city's walls...
Then suddenly, two huge serpents emerged from the nearby waters. As we scattered desperately to save ourselves, they moved with intent, targeting Laocoon, the most adament rejector of the horse.

In each of their great jaws they clutched one of his young sons, gnawing on their wretched limbs. Laocoon ran to save them, armed with a spear, but was caught between the bodies of the two beasts. They wrapped around him, mercilessly, until his cries of agony faltered.
After this brutal display, the creatures slithered over to a statue of Pallas, curling around the goddess' feet and resting there- we could not ignore such an clear message.

So we rolled the huge horse into the city, resting it at the center of our great town. We spent our last day in those great walls celebrating, rejoicing at the end of the war and our triumph over the Greeks. At nightfall, we had all returned homes, and even those stationed at our defenses were cloaked in a deep drowsiness.

Oblivious to the start of the final Greek attack, I was visited by a dream. An anguished Hector appeared to me, tears streaming down his face, covered in dust and gore. He was not the proud, powerful leader I remembered, but a defeated, disheveled version of himself, bearing the countless wounds received during his defending of our city.
I addressed him sorrowfully and asked him why he appeared to me in such a state. With a deep sigh, he only responded:
"Child of Venus, you must escape this city. The walls are taken, Troy has fallen- the city now trusts its legacy with you. Leave, find some place across the sea and build new walls for our people."
I awoke to the surrounding roar of battle. Scrambling to the rooftop, I heard the rage of the Greeks flooding our city, and watched fires consume and collapse familiar buildings.

choices.text: I had to flee, saving as much as I could
I had to fight- there was still a chance to save the city

text: I gathered my weapons and was met at my door by a priest of Phoebus. "This is the last day of our nation. The horse pours out endless Greek troops, who have filled every corner of our city. Our guards can scarcely survive a single single clash."
I led my familiar comrades into the greatest fight of their lives. In a frenzy we pressed through hordes of Greeks towards the heart of our city and certain death.

We passed through the carnage, generations of our empire slaughtered, bodies scattered all around the city. We stumbled into a troop of Greek soldiers, who mistook us for allies. We swarmed them and killed them in their confusion, stealing their armor in hopes of tricking our enemies.
We saw Priam's daughter, the princess Cassandra, dragged out of Minerva's temple. We rushed to help her, forcing our way to the densent parts of the battle.
But now the Greek forces began to overwhelm us, seeing through or new disguises. My men began to fall, but we continued to fight, still hoping to protect our doomed city.

Hearing commotion within Priam's palace, my surviving forces ran to help. We saw Trojan forces desperately battling to protect the palace gates, barely keeping the Greek forces at bay. Pyrrhus, Achilles' son, led them, forcing his way into the palace, neither locks nor guards slowing him.
The Greeks smashed through the great entrance with a battering ram, streaming into the room with murderous ferocity. They overpowered us, destroying everything and everyone in their wake.
Priam, in desperation, strapped on his armor and sword, last used decades before, and rushed to die in the great battle.
He met Queen Hecuba in their courtyard, who stopped him, asking him to protect his family instead. He waited in that courtyard until his son Polites rushed in, chased by Pyrrhus and his bloodlust.
Reaching his father's sight, Polites fell, Pyrrhus' inflicted wounds too great for him. Outraged, Priam flung his spear at Pyrrhus, pitifully cast aside by Pyrrhus' bronze shield.

Achilles' son dragged the Priam to the courtyard altar, slipping in his own son's blood. Forcing the king onto the altar, Pyrrhus thrust his sword deep into the king's chest, killing him as he watched Troy burn.
Once the monarch of an unconquerable empire, his body now lies abandoned on its shore, a headless, nameless thing.
Now I was filled with a profound horror- in the king's savage demise I seemed to see my father. I thought of my wife and son, alone and defenseless in our home.

I had to go save them. Looking around for any help, I realized I was completely alone. In their terror, the surviving Trojans had abandoned me, jumping from walls or flinging themselves into the raging fires.

Then I noticed a skulking figure, Helen, a Fury for both nations, betraying both the Trojans and the Greeks. I thought to myself, "Why should she safely return to her homeland, to triumph as a queen? Priam is butchered, Troy is burning- to execute a woman brings no honor, but I must destroy this evil to bring justice for those who have lost their lives."

Overwhelming fury carried me towards her, until my mother appeared and restrained me. "My child, give up your hatred of Helen- it is the gods who have doomed Troy. Go to your family, who you have abandoned. If not for my protection, Greek weapons and flames would have already consumed them. I can protect you and guide you to escape from these crumbling walls."
I saw the truth in my mother's message- it was more urgent to save my family than slaughter Paris' helpless wife.
Hidden away in a dark mist, I rushed through the collapsing city to my home,
